prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

But the question is whether that response was wrong. The friend's behavior was definitely problematic, making untrue and insulting remarks. However, the author's reply was also a personal attack, pointing out the friend's situation. Even if the statement is true, the way it was delivered might have been too harsh or not the best approach. 

The mutual friends think the author is entitled, so maybe the author's tone or the content of the message came off as judgmental. Even if the author's intention was to be honest, the response might have been more about pointing out the friend's flaws rather than offering support. 

Also, considering the friend's history of insults, the author was likely feeling defensive. But responding with a direct criticism, even if it's the "truth," can be seen as crossing a line. It might be better to address the insults by setting boundaries without attacking the friend's personal life. 

So, while the friend definitely was in the wrong for the ongoing insults, the author's response might not have been the best way to handle it. The author could have expressed their feelings about the insults without making a personal attack. Therefore, the author is partially at fault for responding in a way that escalated the conflict, even if the friend was being an ass.

Hmm, but maybe the author was just being honest. However, in a friendship, even if someone is being insulting, the way you respond matters. The key is whether the author's response was a valid form of self-defense in the context of the relationship. If the friend was consistently attacking the author, the author might feel justified in pointing out the cause of the friend's issues. But in reality, making a personal critique about someone's life choices, even if true, can be hurtful and might not be helpful. 

I think the answer hinges on whether the author's statement was a proportionate response to the insults. The friend's comments were personal and untrue, so the author's response, while truthful, was also personal. It's possible that the author's response was a valid defense, but it's also possible that the mutual friends' reactions show that the author's response wasn't well-received and caused more harm. 

In conclusion, the author might not be entirely wrong for responding the way they did, given the context of ongoing insults. However, there might have been a better way to communicate the same point without attacking the friend's personal life, which could have been more productive.
